title: Thoughts on technology and higher education
author: dansker34
post_content: I'm posting this under the assumption that the varied roles of technology in higher education have perhaps taken a wrong turn, and one which threatens the ability of higher education to respond to a world it claims to understand.  The primary claim I make is that higher education circles, both faculty structures and administrative units have chosen, or have chosen for them technologies which invite individual creativity, but in the end hamper coordination and intergration key for both faculty and administrators alike. The sources appear to range from inappropriate fascination with the promise of open source code, to the dominance of Unix systems to manage domain control as well as drive university websites.  On the opposite end, the rise intrinsically integrating systems driven by enterprise class relational databases working in tandem with J2EE and Visual Studio have been dismissed as supposedly too corporate. In reality, I think it reveals an absence of understanding of current administrative tools and their strengths.  This weblog invites thoughtful discussion on these topic from any and all sources.

title: Making the call
author: James
post_content: What a tangled web we weave when first we practice a political and financial clusterfuck. The nasdaq 100 trust, symbol QQQ is comprised of 100 companies that trade on the NASDAQ exchange, the NYSE's little brother. This effectively is a mutual fund for the top 100 Nasdaq companies. Ebay, cisco and many other internet bubble era stocks make up this little time bomb. As usual, the two years prior to an election, the govt does everything within its power to turn any perilous economic tides so their regime can stay in power for another go-round. Here we are, 5 months out and the propoganda machine is in full force "more jobs are being created, the stock market is doing 20% better than a yera ago today". Stocks as a whole are overpriced, the techs and other profitless wonders such as Amazon.com have been flying the last 2 years. Once the election party is over, and booze no longer floweth, our hangover will soon set in. "How do you know this" you're asking. I don't, I have no magic pills or Nostradamian vision, but history is a great predictor of the future. Historically stocks trade at a PRICE/EARNINGS ratio of around 15. Ebay and Cisco are now at 108 and 36 respectively. There are a confluence of other factors that will turn the economic tide in the coming months. The price of oil, interest rates increasing, the successful or unsuccessful detachment from Iraq that is supposed to occur this summer, as well as issues with china are all concerns. My not-so-crystal ball tells me that we can count on at least two of those things increasing in severity and negatively affecting the market. So, stocks are overpriced, shit and fan are soon to meet. I see a few ways to play this. I'll set the time horizon as a year from the election, roughly a year and a half from today. The risky play with a chance for doubling your money would be buying  QQQ puts (options, that win if the stock goes down) with a January 2006 expiration. Enough time to let the shit hit the fan, and enough lag time to bail out of the position if the time doesnt turn after this election. I like the $36 puts, they demand a $4 per share premium, which means you would make a dime until the stocks drops below $32, but glancing at the 2 year chart it seems highly likely. In the year following the previous election, EBays value dropped by half, along with many others that comprise the QQQ play. Better odds than blackjack, and you have the option to pull out if you dont like how the cards are laid out in the next few months. The middle of the road play would be gold stocks. Not cheap today either, but cheap by comparision, and classically they thrive when the Index's fall. I like Goldcorp (my major holding), AEM,and NEM, for stable plays, IAG and GSS for riskier plays. The other obvious option is to warm the bench and watch the action from the sidelines. People often do in down markets because they dont understand how to make money when the market falls. Next blog will explain that.

post_content: <blockquote><div align="justify"><span style="font-size:100%;">Well here I am almost a year since I set this page up, making my first post. One of my resolutions (well u can’t really call it a resolution) for this year was to maintain a journal. But then the year got off to a rollercoaster start and before two weeks had gone by I had landed in the US of A. In the midst of all the relocation n stuff maintaining my journal was tough! I just got one page done – which sucked. Besides, what was I thinking with the ol’ paper n pen stuff anyways! So well that explains why I am finally here. I hope to capture my reflections here hence forth. Considering that I m new to this it may take a while for my posts to mature. But since I m writing this for myself – I don’t care what any person (I ‘d be lucky) who stops by may think – at least for now (Sorry folks – don’t intend to sound rude). So here goes…<br /><br />I was sent across to Silver Spring, MD for a project with a major telecom provider in the US from my company back home in India. Well I m not getting into details which are reserved only for people who know me. Had a very long flight considering the 7hrs transit time ( 3hrs at Dubai and 4 at Paris), but then who gets to see Dubai International, Charles De Gaule and Dulles Intl, Washington in a single trip. All of em real neat airports in their own way. Luckily had some guys here who could pick me up (though 2hrs late – Dulles is huger than it appears) and put me up for the first couple of weeks!<br /><br />From this evening I ll be in my own apartment. Setting up a place and stocking it was not an easy task in the least for me n my roomie coz we lacked our own wheels and weather did’nt help either – its just stopped snowing. Not having a Social Security No. is the worst thing. Everything in this country is driven by it! We should be pretty much settled down in the coming week if everything works as planned. On the professional side – well u bet there’s been loads happening – lots which I can’t put here. But I guess this is a lot for a single post – so I ll sift through those details and add later.</span></div></blockquote>

title: Suicide
author: [A.Z.]
post_content: We wake, before dawn,<br />bleary-eyed, spirits low,<br />And we rush, our time scarce,<br />morning exercises, to start the day.<br />A tasteless breakfast, then we march,<br />stiff and weary, herded like cattle,<br />sergeants screaming, timer chanting,<br />the steps we take, to our next ordeal.<br />We toil, we sweat,<br />we run, we pant,<br />we shout, throats hoarse,<br />heads bowed, hopes gone.<br />Our rifles spit, the grenades blow, <br />we recoil, only to be driven forth,<br />no time to think, no time to stop,<br />just rush and rush, until we fall.<br />We try our best, push our limits,<br />to do it once, to do it right,<br />but the slightest falter, that's it, we're gone,<br />guard duty strikes, our weekends lost.<br /><br />It's too hard sometimes.<br /><br />Why do we do this? Is there<br />a reason, is there a meaning,<br />to what we face each day? Is it<br />for the small patch of land<br />that can barely fit us all? Is it<br />for the embellished, over-advertised ideals<br />of an age long past? Or is it<br />for the people you call family, that <br />girl who possessed your heart, from whom<br />you left for this island of hopeless toil?<br /><br />I can't answer that question,<br />for we are the bald ones, those fated<br />to act on orders without thinking,<br />those who are not supposed to think. So,<br />we can only accept our fate, take <br />what is our due, and stoically march on,<br />hoping we'll find a meaning to this someday.

title: Sunday May 16th
author: Niss
post_content: Despite doing a remarkable amount of nazel gazing over the past year, I've managed to completely neglect this blog!  I'd like to use the "best of intentions" excuse, but reading my one and only post I realise I was merely looking for a means of time-wasting.<br />Just over twelve months on and on the other side of the globe, I'm still as adept at killing the hours.  Daydreaming is my preferred form of escapism of late. <br />Travelling back to Australia via Panama and Costa Rica was incredible - I could spend my whole life travelling.  24 hours after we left frozen, post-Christmas London I was sitting on a balcony in San Jose, sipping the local brew and watching the sun set on deepening purple.  It was one of those moments of excruciating longing without knowing exactly what it is we long for.<br />Now London feels like a dream.  The only evidence I have of ever living there is an extra five kilos and a recreational drug habit.<br />Andrew and I have found our own place in Brunswick, which is blissful after living with seven boisterous Aussies in Shepherds Bush.  I now work for a less pointy-end of the cause - the Environment Department in local government.  I enjoy my work and being surrounded by like-minded, passionate people... but being confined to an office is difficult!  Many a wistful gaze I cast out the window, reminiscing about sultry mid-summer London and Acton Park Lodge.  If instead of writing that last post I'd have walked outside to the lodge garden, I would've been treated to the hum of dragonflies which decorate the pond.  I may have caught the burnt orange tail of our resident fox disappearing behind the back fence.  My head would have filled with the intoxicating smell of things growing.<br />The screen's becoming blurry behind my magenta-coloured glasses.   Australia is equally beautiful - I just feel out of touch with nature in my current office-bound position.  Coming home to a patch of concrete and callistemon in the back garden just doesn't really cut it!  I miss the open-mindedness of people in London too, and the willingness of other transients to make friends.<br />I'm off to have a glass of wine with my boy.  I spend enough time staring at a screen at work, and he looks like he needs a hug tonight.  Here's hoping I'll be needing to purge my thoughts / waste some time again shortly- I might actually manage a THIRD entry!

title: Kill Bill Volume 1
author: Vincent
post_content: Les Décimales Du Futur (aka The Final Program aka The Last Days Of Man On Earth) ne sont pas aussi mauvaises que ça. Bien sûr, ça ne vaut aucun vieux film de l'âge d'or d'Hollywood (comme Carioca que j'ai vu hier) mais c'est assez marrant. C'est rigolo de voir à quel point Robert Fuest prenait son entreprise au sérieux : dire de ce film que "la science fiction n'ira jamais plus loin" était sans doute exagéré. Depuis Phibes, Fuest était sur la pente descendante. Après The Final Program, il réalisera Aphrodite, allant toujours plus loin dans la veine érotique, déjà bien présente dans TFP (on croirait le nom d'un bouquet satellite). C'est un film jouissif à toutes sortes de niveaux : voir Jon Finch dans sa Rolls se verser du scotch dans un gobelet en carton et en foutre plein par terre c'était déjà assez réjouissant, mais le numéro des trois scientifiques habillés comme des truands dans un film de Lautner est encore plus réussi. Ce film n'a pas usurpé sa réputation de film culte, même si Fuest abuse quand même des effets de couleur.

title: Thank God for Good Friends
author: Sunflowers of Passion
post_content: Hinges that need a good squirt of oil is what is needed in this situation. It's been a long time since I have written anything down. The question that I have asked myself so far when I have looked back on my previous posts is whether or not I am completely satisfied with what I have achieved so far and I can honestly say that the answer is no. I do not wish to put a negative spin on things, it's just that I need to take some time to reflect on what I can do to help myself accomplish more in life so that I can make my life meaningful and beneficial.<br /><br />I am all about achieving something better than what I have. It is the way that the task is taken on, by the horns of the bull, sort of speak, that I tend to focus and learn. Otherwise nothing gets accomplished. So what needs to be addressed at this moment that is in full frontal view in my life? What have I not looked at or avoided because I was too afraid to persevere? Is this goal attainable? Have I thought of one, or are there some in the process of achieving? There are always goals to achieve.<br /><br />Some might say that we focus our energy into some things because we are too scared to look at the bigger picture. Has it ever happened to you that you suddenly feel like vacuuming the car when you have a really important paper due? Or watched a few hours of TV when you really could use that time towards something more meaningful? I am so flighty when it comes to really focusing on what I want. When am I going to learn to put the blinders on and just focus! Or as one of the roofers said once, just fucus! (He had an accent)<br /><br />So I am going to ask myself these questions:<br /><br />1.     What is it that I want to do with my life?<br /><br />2.     What kind goal is important to me that I can achieve in the near future?<br /><br />3.     When can that goal be achieved?<br /><br />4.     Are there goals that I am achieving right now that are benefital to that future accomplishment?<br /><br />5.     If so what are they?<br /><br /><br />Now the first question I think is very broad, and it takes a lot of effort to really think of an answer for that one, because what I want to do with my life isn't necessarily what I am going to get, but I have to put in the efforts to make it happen. Before I reap the rewards, I have to sow the seeds. So that's why the next question needs to be addressed.<br /><br />The second question addresses things like job related, health related, education related.... etc. You may have something in mind like wanting to lose 50 lbs, or wanting to further a career path, or making time to schedule in a few courses. Make that goal attainable, realistic and use time frames so that you know that you have a fixed schedule to achieve something. <br /><br />If there is no time schedule, then I'm pretty sure that the goal will not be achieved. So I have a few goals in mind. To obtain my degree. When will that be achieved? I don't really know exactly but I wish to take no longer than 6 years since I am going part time. To date I have 30 credits under my belt, and I am currently taking 12. I need 120 to graduate. So that leaves me with 78 credits to get. Or 13 six credit courses. The price that I will pay may be about $15,000 more or plus. So I will see how it will go. <br /><br />Another thing that I have always had an issue with is my weight. I am currently around 230 lbs. I have even gone as far as to think of perhaps looking into gastric laparoscopic surgery. I have written an email to a surgeon in my area and got a response. The estimated amount this might cost me depending on the route that I take is approximately $15,000. So right now getting surgery is not an option and it is a last desperate cry I believe. So what are the alternatives?<br /><br />Diet and exercise, seems to be a reasonable suggestion yes? I think so too. I feel though I have too much on my plate right now. Working part time, and school part time... trying to fit in things all together is difficult, and requires a lot of organization. *And all I see right now are excuses to not go out and do something about it.* Let's focus on the positive instead... So in the past summer, I went out and joined the walking club. I did a 10k walk with them, and I really enjoyed it.<br /><br />If I could perhaps, get back to a regular routine of getting up early and going to the gym. Getting up at say 7:30 and going to the gym for 2 hours, I would have enough time to go home and get ready for work by 12. I also was given a gift certificate to a personal trainer. Have I used it yet? No, not yet. But I am planning to use it when I go back to weight watchers. I think that's the route I'm going to take again. I have tried alternatives, such as TOPS (take off the pounds sensibly) but I think the best route so far has been WW, plus they meet on a day when I can make it to their meetings.<br /><br />So when do I plan to make this all happen? What am I going to really focus on doing? I am going to say this. By some time in April, I plan on going back to weight watchers. When this happens, and when I start making this an on going thing (Remember the alternative how much it would cost for surgery?) I am going to start talking to someone at the gym about obtaining a personal trainer. If I don't do this, I am going to post a picture of myself that I don't like.<br /><br />So what is the plan?<br /><br />Start getting up early and going to the gym.<br /><br />By April, join WW.<br /><br />By my birthday: Get a trainer.<br /><br />If I don't do these things by my birthday: Ugly picture of me on the internet! Eep O_o<br /><br />There's motivation for you! Bye for now.. see you next update.

Two years later, haha.<br /><br />It looks like I left readers with a huge cliff-hanger.<br /><br />Sorry about that.<br /><br />Life has been weird for me still.. my family still ignores me, I have tons of friends that I'm not sure I even care about, and I work crazily. title: LostArchivesOfTheBrazosportNews
author: Banjo Jones
post_content: 9.26.2001 <br />Remain calm<br /><br />Scooter has been wandering around the house singing “God Bless America.”<br />Barbra Streisand, the ultraliberal Bush basher, has pulled articles critical of the Administration off her web site.<br />National news commentators called President Bush’s speech to Congress last week one of the best speeches in the history of our country.<br />So what does our County Judge do in the midst of this almost unprecedented national unity? He sends out a memo telling county employees not to misuse the county’s electronic mail system.<br />That doesn’t exactly set you to whistling “Yankee Doodle Dandy.”<br />Background: a tax office employee sent out an email relating an incident she said she heard occurred at an Angleton convenience store, where the owner supposedly said “America got what it deserved” in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.<br />The email got passed around hither and yon, as emails tend to do in times like these.<br />Some way the email made its way to the county judge’s office.<br />The email writer said in her missive that the convenience store owner who uttered the anti-American statement ought to be shut down.<br />Now, we don’t know if the Angleton convenience store owner really said what he supposedly said.<br />If he did, well, that’s OK, though unfortunate. There’s still free speech in this country, both for the email writer and the convenience store fellow (if he really exists).<br />But was it really necessary for Judge Willy to issue a formal statement that announced the county wouldn’t tolerate misuse of the email system to target individuals or groups?<br />Couldn’t he have just picked up the phone and told the employee to knock it off, to calm down, to take a chill pill?<br />I guarantee you, word would have got around the courthouse after that.<br />But instead the judge issues the formal statement to employees, department heads and elected officials. Which of course gets in the local newspaper. Very unnecessary.<br />Sometimes it’s better to work underneath the radar.<br />Now is not the time for anyone to carried away.<br />It’s not time for traditional-looking Americans (you decide what that means) to bash Americans who don’t look like traditional Americans, and it’s not time for our elected officials to hit the panic button over an email writer who got a little carried away one day.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 8:41 PM <br />9.21.2001 <br /><br />Scenes from a hospital<br /><br />I had never spent much time in an intensive care unit, never as patient and only this past week because my father has been seriously ill.<br />The waiting room is where you see the families gather. Some are in tears, others stare blankly at the TV. There is a phone for family and friends on the outside to call in for progress reports.<br />When it rings, whooever’s nearest the phone picks it up. If it’s not for them, they find out who the caller is seeking, then calls out their last name. Nobody minds answering the phone, it gives them something to do besides wait.<br />You see the same faces day in, day out, and a casual familiarity soon grows. You find out a little about why your fellow ICU-waiters are there and you tell them why you’re present.<br />The TV news, even when it’s about momentous events such as the pending war against Osama Bin Laden, is of only passing interest because the crisis with which you’re dealing is much closer to the heart.<br />There is so much tension that any humor spills out suddenly in a rush, providing a welcome release.<br />In our case, another family’s daily and nightly watch had coincided with ours. Scooter, being the friendly half of our duo, had gotten to know their story.<br />Their ICU patient was only about 50 years old and his future time on this Earth was tenuous. They were holding up well, though. The patient’s wife, his 20-something son, his sister in-law and a few other relatives or friends were there every day.<br />They’d mostly sit and chat among themselves about family doings, or what the cafeteria down the hall was serving for lunch or other innocuous matters.<br />One day a preacher showed up. They weren’t on a first-name basis with the man, so they must not have been active church-goers, but he introduced himself with a smile after he made his entrance.<br />The wife of the ICU patients spoke up and met the preacher, who then turned to the woman beside her and said, “And you must be the mom.”<br />There were blank looks all around until the woman said, “No, I’m her sister.”<br />There was a second or two of uneasy silence until the son of the ICU patient, who was seated on the other side of the room, put his hand over his mouth to stifle a guffaw.<br />Then he turned to shoot Scooter a wide-eyed look of “Ohmygosh!”<br />Scooter, who was undergoing her own massive dosage of stress due to my father’s illness, saw the son’s reaction, then burst out in a laugh before she was able to put her own hand over her mouth.<br />Then everyone else chuckled.<br />The preacher apologized, said he was praying for the patient and then he left.<br />Then the entire room burst out into loud laughter.<br />The gray-haired woman who was mistaken for her sister’s mother said she guessed she’d have to start tinting her hair again.<br />“I’ve had every color there is,” she observed dryly.<br />The case of mistaken identity was good for everyone, taking our minds off the life-and-death matters at hand. The gray-haired lady obviously did not mind the humor coming at her expense.<br />The next day, my dad was transferred to another hospital. I walked beside him as his stretcher was wheeled out. I knew that family was watching me as I followed Dad out to the ambulance, but I didn’t look their way.<br />I heard them say “good luck.”<br />I don’t know if their patient made it out of the ICU alive but I hope he did, and so far, my 80-year-old dad, who’s never spent more than a few hours in a hospital in his entire life, is still with us.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 3:22 PM <br />9.14.2001 <br /><br /><br />A poem for these times<br /><br />"There is sobbing of the strong,<br />And a pall upon the land;<br />But the People in their weeping<br />Bare the iron hand;<br />Beware the People weeping<br />When they bare the iron hand."<br /><br />- Herman Melville, "The Martyr," upon the death of Abraham<br />Lincoln.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 10:00 PM <br /><br />9.13.2001 <br /><br />Come together<br /><br />There is a rally/prayer service at 7:30 p.m. Friday at the Lake Jackson Civic Center where all of us can show our support for our country, the president and the people who were murdered in New York, Washington, D.C., and Pennsylvania on Tuesday.<br />We don’t care if you’re a Christian, a Moslem, an atheist or an anarchist, this is your chance to show that you care.<br /><br /><br />posted by Banjo Jones 1:54 PM <br /><br /><br />After the attack, remembering a victim<br /><br />Yesterday, Scooter went out to the garage and found our American flag, which she’s had since the nation celebrated its Bicentennial in 1976.<br />She unfurled it and went out to the front yard to stick it in one of our big planters, where we try to grow roses. <br />By the end of the day, three more of our neighbors were flying their flags. Others in other neighborhoods around town were flying theirs, too.<br />She’s also said she’s going to send back her $300 federal tax cut money with a note telling whoever’s in charge of such matters to use the money to help someone affected by the terrorist attack on Tuesday.<br />She’s too old to enlist in the Army. Otherwise, she’d probably be filling out an application as I write this.<br />You feel powerless in the face of such events. You watch it on TV, read about it on the Internet and in the newspapers, talk to your friends about it and not much else.<br />Scooter told me this morning she knows one of the victims in the World Trade Center attack.<br />His name was Chris Jeffreys. She went to his wedding about 14 years ago.<br />“He was a poor boy from Michigan who became very rich and wealthy, moved to New York City and expanded his empire,” she said. “He bought homes on the East and West Coast, apartments in Manhattan and mansions in the Hamptons, flats in London and villas in the South of France. As a person he was just real down to earth. He never forgot where he was from. He enjoyed showing his friends the good life he had acquired and he enjoyed sharing everything with his friends. He was very, very generous. Very generous. He would invite you to Deer Valley (Utah) and wouldn’t let you spend a dime. His daughter’s 13th birthday party was on a yacht in New York Harbor. He’d send you an airline ticket and an invitation and put you up at The Plaza. Donald Trump was at his wedding. He was just a very kind and generous person.”<br />“I’m just still kind of numb about it. I just keep thinking about his daughter. He adored her. Just adored her. You can’t imagine. She’s probably 26 now. If anyone made the most out of life, Chris did.”<br />“He was from a no advantage type of background. He worked his way through Michigan law school. His dad was some kind of steelworker. He didn’t go to law school to practice law. He went to law school to find out how to manuever through the business world and to get out of where he was and on to a better life. He was just driven, really driven. That comes from being poor.”<br />Now this generous man who exemplifies the best part of the American Dream is gone, along with thousands of others.<br />Scooter’s mother called last night to report she was having lunch at her government office when she overheard some coworkers, who were ardent, outspoken supporters of Al Gore in the last election.<br />She said she overheard them talking while they watched the news on television.<br />“Thank God this is the group that was in charge of the Gulf War,” she quoted them as saying.<br />Scooter’s mom, a gung ho Republican, said she bit her tongue.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 10:26 AM <br />9.11.2001 <br /><br />Close to home<br /><br />I heard the news of the World Trade Center on the radio, in my car.<br />It wasn’t until a few hours later that I saw the TV pictures.<br />The airliner crashing into the skyscraper looked like some kind of video game. Not real at all. Just an image on a screen.<br />You half expected the TV screen to flash Game Over, then resume with a new video image of an intact World Trade Center, before the image of the airliner would re-appear and head for the tall building again.<br />If only it worked that way. If only you could take a joystick, make a few quick manuevers, push a few buttons, and save the world.<br />Then I remembered.<br />I HAVE A NIECE WHO LIVES IN MANHATTAN. <br />I called my sister to see if she’s heard anything from Kelley, her daughter, who’s a student at New York University.<br />I got her answering machine.<br />Scooter already had talked to my mother, who said my sister couldn’t find a map of New York City. She remembered the street where Kelley lives, but she needed a map to figure out how close it might be to the World Trade Center.<br />But Scooter remembered. She remembered Kelley was living on Water Street. And she’s been to New York City enough to know that Water Street is real close to the World Trade Center.<br />Several hours went by. No word from my sister. I took a nap. Scooter stayed glued to the TV.<br />Then, a few minutes ago, my sister called.<br />Her daughter, Kelley, a sophomore at NYU, was alright.<br />She said she was riding the shuttle bus to class this morning when she noticed some papers flying around in the air.<br />She thought it odd.<br />Then she looked up and saw the second explosion.<br />My sister started crying when she told me her daughter was unharmed.<br />As for Kelley, she went on to class after witnessing the explosion. Her dormitory, five blocks from the World Trade Center, is closed.<br />The ATM she uses is right across the street from the World Trade Center.<br />“She could have been there,” my sister said, breaking up.<br />Yes, she could have, but she wasn’t, and for that I am grateful.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 4:28 PM <br />9.9.2001 <br /><br />POLITICS<br /><br /><br />back scratchin'<br /><br />If you were watching the Astros game on the tube last weekend like we were, you may have noticed two familiar faces sitting in the $200 seats directly behind home plate, where Astros owner Drayton McLane sits.<br />It was our state Sen. Buster Brown and Judge Ben Hardin.<br />Whenever the camera from centerfield panned the batter's box, you could see the two of them enjoying our National Pasttime.<br />We don't who was paying for the Cokes and popcorn, but it wouldn't surprise us if the judge was paying the freight.<br />Sen. Buster got George W. Bush, who was governor at the time, to appoint him to the job after Neil Caldwell retired to his fingerpaints back in '95.<br />Anyhow, a number of people thought someone else should have been appointed to the judicial vacancy, someone of more judicial depth and experience than Ben Hardin.<br />Sen. Buster didn't see it that way, and since he's the politico who holds sway around here, that's what counts.<br />Which is why Sen. Buster, by coincidence we're sure, gets appointed by Judge Hardin to lend his expert mediation services to all those cases in the 23rd Judicial District.<br /><br />dude, where's my raise?<br /><br />The politician with the coolest name in Texas, Prct. 1 County Commissioner Dude Payne, has laid claim to the Populist of the Year trophy by virtue of his stance on a pay raise for himself.<br />"I knew what this job paid when I ran for it," Dude was quoted as saying when he pooh-poohed the idea of hiking pay for the county's elected officials.<br />That's very Gary Cooperesque.<br />Or John Waynesque, if you prefer.<br />We have a hard time picturing his predecessor opining such a notion to the media unless he was talking about the price of the grilled cheese sandwiches down at the county airport's lunch counter.<br />Could it be that the man called Dude will surpass Ronnie Broaddus as a bonafide man of the people?<br />Despite his obvious shortcomings, which were well documented in the files of the DA's office, Broaddus cut a wide swath when he would pull such stunts as marching to the courthouse toting a picket sign that bashed his favorite whipping boy, Dow Chemical.<br />Such antics don't fit Dude's job description, but if he keeps dishing out those heaping helpings of Humble Pie, he will be a fixture at the courthouse for a long time.<br /><br />"me no Alamo"<br /><br />The Democrats and the Republicans are stumbling over themselves to become one with their brown brothers and sisters.<br />The Dems have found a rich Hispanic to run for governor and now the Rs are angling to get an Hispanic congressman appointed U.S. Senator.<br />It's the new Millenium's answer to Nixon's Southern Strategy in the late '60s, when Tricky Dick turned the Democrats on their heads by wooing Dixiecrat voters away from the party of FDR.<br />Back then, Nixon appealed to a Silent Majority.<br />The new Silent Majority are Hispanics.<br />You don't hear a politician promising a chicken in every pot any more, but you may hear one promising frijoles in every microwave in the coming years.<br />At least one politician says Texans will never elect an Hispanic to the governor's office.<br />That man is John Worldpeace, a Houston lawyer running for governor who routinely refers to Gov. Rick Perry as "the Republican devil Rick Perry."<br />Native Texan white voters over 50 years of age are too prejuduiced to vote for an Hispanic as governor principally due to racism that dates back to the massacres at Goliad and the Alamo, says Worldpeace.<br />That’s a politically incorrect statement, of course, even from a crackpot, but the leaders of the Democratic and Republican parties in our state have shown that whatever truth may lie in that sentiment is no longer politically viable.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 1:00 AM <br />9.1.2001 <br /><br />The Vigil<br /><br /><br />Michael was 13 when he was hit by the car.<br />His father called Scooter from the hospital and told her that his son was going to die.<br />He was running across a freeway when he was hit. The impact knocked him out of his shoes, crushed his body.<br />Michael was still in his bloody clothes when Scooter got to the hospital.<br />He was in a deep, deep coma and not expected to live.<br />That’s when the vigil began.<br />Scooter’s memories of that horrible time were evoked when we recently heard that the young boy in Florida who had been attacked by a shark had been sent home while he was still in a coma.<br />When Michael was hit by the car, the family was still grieving over a tragedy that occurred 12 years earlier. Michael’s sister Little Tia, only 2 years old at the time, was killed when she fell out of the car after the door came open.<br />Now it appeared likely Michael would join his sister.<br />After the first two days, when he surprised the doctors by surviving, they fixed his leg, inserting pins to mend it.<br />But the only way he could breathe was on a ventilator, and there were no signs that he would soon rejoin the world as a conscious human being.<br />The Tribe, as Scooter’s family calls themselves, stayed by his bed, arriving and leaving in shifts, but the doctor offered no encouragement that he would regain consciousness.<br />“You’d lift up his eyes and it was like no one was there,” Scooter remembers.<br />But every day, Scooter made the 45-minute drive to the hospital. She didn’t give the least intimation to her nephew that his situation was grave.<br />“Hi, Michael! It’s Scooter. How’re you today?” she’d say upon entering his hospital room.<br />He didn’t respond, of course, but the greeting stayed the same.<br />The doctors said he couldn’t hear her, but Scooter decided from the beginning that he could hear every word she spoke.<br />She read books to him like the The Power of Positive Thinking, Creative Visualization and the Bible.<br />She talked to him about what he would do when he woke up, how he was going to ride his bike and play baseball. <br />When there was a ball game on the TV, she’d watch and give him a play-by-play account.<br />After a while, Scooter’s Significant Other at that time told her to quit going to the hospital, it was a waste of time. But she went anyway, every day, as soon as he left the house. She just didn’t tell him.<br />Early in the vigil, Scooter called a close friend named Ed Foreman, a former Congressman from New Mexico who now is a motivational speaker. He was on vacation when she called, but his office tracked him down.<br />He made a tape recording for Michael that Scooter played every day. She told the nurse to turn the tape over if she wasn’t there so her nephew could hear both sides.<br />On the tape, Ed Foreman talked to Michael as if he was sitting in the room with him.<br />“Michael, this is your friend Ed Foreman...”<br />Michael had never met Ed Foreman but Ed talked to him as if they were old friends. He talked to Michael about comas and the unconscious mind. He told him he was going through a challenging time, that his body was healing.<br />He told him that one day he would laugh out loud and people would enjoy being in his company.<br />He told him to breathe deep.<br />From outward appearances, there was no discernible way to tell if Michael was absorbing any of it. At least that’s what the doctors said.<br />But Scooter kept talking and reading, and the Ed Foreman tape kept rolling.<br />The doctors weren’t impressed.<br />One day Scooter walked into the room and Michael’s eyes were open.<br />The doctor said it was involuntary.<br />By then, Michael’s arms and hands had begun to curl up. His muscles had begun to atrophy. A physical therapist showed Scooter how to get his hands open and pull his arms down. That alone took two weeks to accomplish.<br />Though the doctors initially attributed no significance to Michael’s eyes being open, a few weeks later, Scooter said she could see something she hadn’t seen in the beginning.<br />She could tell somebody was in there.<br />“Involuntary tracking,” the doctor said.<br />Then one afternoon a Daffy Duck cartoon was on TV and Scooter could tell he was watching it.<br />“Involuntary tracking,” the doctor said.<br />Six months passed.<br />He was still on a ventilator. The doctors told Scooter and the rest of The Tribe they need to think about placing Michael in a nursing home.<br />“Maybe some day he’ll be able to feed himself,” the doc said.<br />The Tribe argued against the move. They didn’t want to surrender.<br />Then, just before he was to be transferred to a nursing home, Michael caught a cold. He couldn’t be transferred while he was sick. It was like a reprieve from the governor for a condemned man, and it gave Scooter and Co. more time to plead their case. <br />They wanted Michael put in the hospital’s coma unit, instead of a nursing home, but the doctor said he hadn’t shown enough progress.<br />Michael could blink his eyes and squeeze a visitor’s hand, but the doctor said it was meaningless.<br />But Scooter was so persistent, as only Scooter can be, and the doctor finally relented, with one proviso. Michael had to demonstrate he could obey a certain command.<br />“If you can make him stick out his tongue, we’ll put him in the coma unit,” he said.<br />Finally, an opening!<br />For the next two weeks, Scooter went to Michael’s room with a different greeting.<br />“Hi, Michael, it’s your Aunt Scooter. Give me your tongue.”<br />She’d pull his tongue out of his mouth.<br />“OK, now it’s out,” she’d say.<br />Then she’d push it back in.<br />“OK, now it’s back in.”<br />Again and again. Every day for two weeks.<br />When deadline day arrived, The Tribe was besides themselves. Sometimes Michael would stick his tongue out and sometimes he wouldn’t.<br />It was time to do it for the doctor.<br />When the man in the white coat arrived, Scooter said, “OK, Michael, stick out your tongue.”<br />Nothing.<br />“Michael, stick out your tongue.”<br />Nothing.<br />“Michael, stick...”<br />“See? Nursing home,” the doctor said.<br />The doctor, a voice of authoritative pessimism every day for the last six months, turned to walk out of the room.<br />As he was about to go through the door, Michael, like a 6-year-old making a face as soon as his playground nemesis turns his back, stuck out his tongue.<br />“See! See! He stuck out his tongue! He stuck out his tongue!”<br />The doctor stopped. With a sigh, he turned around.<br />“Let me see it again.”<br />And Michael stuck his tongue out in the doctor’s face, as if to say, “THERE! SEE?”<br />“OK,” the doctor said. “Coma unit.”<br />Everyone in the room cried, everyone except the doctor and Michael.<br />In the coma unit, Michael’s tracheotomy tube was removed. The nurses warned The Tribe not to be surprised if his speech sounded infantile because his brain injury may have reduced his intellectual level.<br />Scooter asked Michael if he wanted to listen to music.<br />He nodded yes.<br />“Fat Boys,” he croaked.<br />His request for rap music proved, in Scooter’s mind, that he was still operating at his correct age level -- a 13-year-old boy.<br />Scooter rushed out of the room and found a Fat Boys tape.<br />The next words Michael uttered proved something else.<br />“Who’s Ed Foreman?” he asked.<br />“I just started balling,” Scooter remembers. “I couldn’t believe it.”<br />Michael had been in a coma for seven months.<br />For seven months, he had a tube down his throat and an Ed Foreman tape playing on headphones. For seven months he had nurses poking him with their fingers and with needles to see if he would respond.<br />For seven months, Scooter had caressed his arms every day, to let him know that she and the rest of The Tribe were waiting for him.<br />Michael put his hand on aunt’s hand. “I love you Aunt Scooter,” he said.<br />He spent the next four months working on his speech and motor development. He had to learn how to walk again..<br />“It’s inch by inch. Each day is another inch, a little bit more,” Scooter recalls.<br />She brought him hamburgers and milkshakes from McDonald’s.<br />One day, Scooter asked him, “Where were you, Michael?”<br />He told her he was with God.<br />Michael said, “He told me I didn’t have to come back if I didn’t want to. I had to think about it and then I decided to come back.”<br />Michael said this matter-of-factly, and Scooter took it matter-of-factly.<br />For the next six months, Michael used a walker to get around. He used it to walk to the podium to address his junior high graduation class.<br />Today he wears a brace on his leg.<br />It’s the only visible reminder of his accident. He’s a good-looking young man, dark brown hair, dark moustache. He is 23 years old and has a hearty laugh. He has been working at McDonald’s the last couple years and has been named Employee of the Month three times.<br />He’d rather work and be around people than stay at home, even though it put a stop to his disability benefits.<br />People enjoy his company, just like Ed Foreman told him they would on that tape recording he listened to a long time ago.<br />posted by Banjo Jones 10:33 PM

title: My favorite reason to hate the prospect of Justice Miers
author: proclus
post_content: I had promised myself that I wouldn't comment on the lurid circus that has occupied the first slot in the news of whatever medium for the past week, although it does illustrate some points <em>a propos</em> of the general theme toward which my infrequent posts have tended. But then <a href="http://myfavoriteanathenaeum.blogspot.com/2005/03/please-stop-terri-schiavos-suffering.html">Voracious Reader</a> joined the clamour and, as it were, invited my response. In failing to check myself, I admit I fall prey to that base, nearly universal impulse to prove one of my father's favorite maxims, namely, that opinions are like a---holes: everybody's got one.<br /><br />As a preliminary matter, I should like the score to reflect another victory for my notion that the judiciary remains a largely non-political organ against the efforts of laymen and news media to reduce it to a product of judges' personal whims and politics. If you'll recall, as soon as the Congress passed the act giving jurisdiction to the Western District of Florida, the networks and papers al began to speculate intensely about how "conservative" or "liberal" judges on that district were, as though that issue would somehow be determinative of whether the parents would get their TRO. As it happened, the media's speculation seemed to be borne out in the district court, since the case was assigned to a Clinton appointee who denied the petitions. Encouraged by this succes, Fox News, if memory serves, began to speculate about the ideological composition of the 11th Circuit, noting that they were largely Republican appointees, and quoting some professor from Western South Central Florida Snobby-Eater College of Law and Brake Tuning, or some such, who driveled "if you get two Republicans on the panel, this gets overturned in a heartbeat." As it tuned out, the literal truth of his statement was never put to the test, since the panel comprised two Democrats and a Republican; but the Republican joined the majority that upheld the denial, and it was a Democrat who dissented. Moreover, on the motion for rehearing <em>en banc</em>, only two of the dozen judges voted to grant, meaning that at most one Republican on the entire court disagreed particularly strongly with the district court's ruling.<br /><br />To top it all off, not one of the justices on the Supreme Court even wrote to disagree with the refusal to award emergency relief--not even Justice Scalia, whom the ignorant commonly regard as a tool of Papists and religious conservatives. Indeed, I think Scalia would be the first to recognize what everyone with a decent grasp of federal jurisprudence, regardless of their stake in the result, realized the minute they read the Congress's emergency legislation: there isn't even the shadow of a substantive claim under federal law. Nor, in any circumstance other than this one, would any sensible conservative want there to be. For example, <a href="http://www.nationalreview.com/mccarthy/mccarthy200503250823.asp">Andrew McCarthy</a> groans on about how the Constitution requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt in "death cases." I expect he would, however, be on of the first to come forward in defense of the ability (established in <em>Kansas v. Hendricks</em>) of authorities to prove by clear and convincing evidence the psychological propensity of someone to commit sex crimes and lock him up indefinitely under a civil commitment statute, though the right to liberty is protected by the Constitution in the same breath with the right to life. "How," you say, "can one compare the rights of a sex offender with those of an innocent?" But the law is blind to such distinctions, as it should be. The only recourse would be to alter the standard of proof somewhere in substantive law (although I've never heard of ratcheting it up in a civil case to proof beyond a reasonable doubt). And such an alteration would probably not even be supported by the people, since I doubt many people relish <em>ex ante</em> the thought of being preserved in a ghoulish state of half-death.<br /><br />I'm not quite sure why it is that I seem to agree with nearly everything <a href="http://www.nationalreview.com/buckley/wfb200503231118.asp">William F. Buckley says</a>--even when I would expect him to disagree with me. In particular, I agree with his point that it is analytically unsound to equate affirmative refusal to preserve life with killing. Such a notion, with its sweeping implications for the moral necessity of a welfare state, is more commonly held by the most pinko socialist than the libertarian or institutional conservative. And yet it is precisely what all the rhetoric from the "right to life" culture postulates. This controversy has illustrated a point that went unnoticed in the past several years of Republican ascendancy, namely, that there is little or no inherent ideological union between limited-government conservatism and Christian social conservatism--it is largely a marriage of convenience. The most irksome thing to me about his whole affair is the toll that it may take on the integrity of Republican politics as the party struggles to keep fundamentalists in the fold. Whether we like it or not, Bill Rhenquist is going to be retiring this year, and it's going to be a long row to hoe getting someone to replace him to the right of David Souter unless Democratic obstructionism is overcome. This debacle could provide the perfect sort of ammunition for Democrats to lob, saying that all the Republicans' talk of "judicial activism" is merely a euphemism for judges who come to substantive conclusions that the religious right doesn't like. I also shudder to think that their loss in this case will ignite religious conservatives to try harder to appoint people for their moral rather than legal views; my blood curdles at the thought of a judge who would have granted a stay in this case because he thought it is what Jesus would have done. On the other hand, for the moment, I cannot fault, for example, W's willingness to sign the bill and utter a few platitudes. As a reassurance that our president is in his heart of hearts a true conservative, I was actually pleased to hear that Bush had been sensible enough to sign that law in Texas. It's dreadful to think of people being vegetables on the public nickel. But though I, as an irreligious structural conservative, might prefer if the Republican party were in a position to discard the useful idiots of the religious right like yesterday's linen, we cannot afford the luxury right now, with socialism attracting hordes of its own fanatics. Nevertheless we must remember that, when push comes to shove, there is nothing special impelling religious fundamentalists to prefer the rule of law and limited government if it conflicts with their religious notions.<br /><br />So, then, in conclusion I would cordially disagree with Voracious Reader when she says that concerns of federalism should be subordinated to those of "life and death." Our system of government has been a bulwark to liberty against political storms and the tyrrany of men for hundreds of years; millions of people far better than the thing that lies expiring in a hospice in Pinellas County have died to build and preserve it. The rule of law is not better than the rule of man because it always produces results that we like: it is better because it is the law, impartial and unyielding. I, for one, will raise a glass when the political fuss dies down, and what was once Theresa Marie Schindler Schiavo is finally allowed to finish the death it began fifteen years ago.

title: Creativity and Art
author: Hamada
post_content: "Port Said, gateway to the Red Sea and the Middle East, strategic portal to the fertile Nile valley and the sprawling Arabian desert, colorful gem of a city that overlooks the vast realm of Egypt, a land of fabulous natural wonders, man-made wonders and enchantment.<br /><br />But there is much more. Perhaps nowhere else in the world does the ancient order meet the modern with more dramatic impact. Huddled among million dollar industries--shipping, oil, spices, foodstocks, mining and skills--lies a kind of "no man's land" into which most of the non-white classes are crammed. Here, in one of the most densely populated regions of the world, thousands of human beings from every corner of the world live in surroundings that defy description.<br /><br />Here exotic women and mysterious men of every sort intermingle. Here peddlers, dancers, wandering musicians, beggars, soldiers of fortune, merchants, thieves, prostitutes, bakers, candlestick makers and drug addicts rub elbows. Here for western consumption, is embodied all the strange and titillating allure of the exotic Middle East.<br /><br />Port Said is a place in which every individual can find something to suit his or her taste. It doesn't matter what one's favorite pastime or personal idea of pleasure may be. There are open markets where one can buy--or be fleeced--almost anything one wishes from soda pop to an oriental dagger or opium pipe. There are dancing girls who will perform their ancient ritual for a few modest coins (and for a little more will take you into their tent or hut for more enjoyable entertainment). An endless parade of native women fills the streets as they go to and from the market or home carrying urns, woven blankets or other burdens on their heads.<br /><br />Almost at every turn there is a pottery merchant who piles his wares to all who cross his spot in the open street. Every now and then the wind wafts the familiar smell of the harbor through the crowded streets, reminding one that Port Said stands at the entrance to the Suez Canal, through which pours an endless caravan of vessels from all over the world. Occasionally you see a camel alongside a streamlined automobile, one of the most striking reminders that co-existence of the old and the new is still very real.<br /><br />And through it all runs the pattern of music, a fascinating and distinctive variety of primitive instruments and equally primitive forms of vocal expression. Compared with western music, modern Egyptian music has changed little from the music of the ancient world. There is a good deal of repetition, but this is one of the elements that makes Egyptian music somewhat ritualistic, and much more interesting to listen to. Even today, for the most part, no fixed harmony or notation is used. The scale is a quarter tone, rather than the western diatonic half tone, scale.<br /><br />Like ancient Egyptian music, the modern variety makes much use of a large variety of instruments, including drums, flutes, bells, cymbals, castanets, clarinets, oboes and strings. Also, a considerable number of different kinds of percussion sticks are used to accompany the music and singing.<br /><br />The music in this recording, typical of authentic Egyptian style, is the kind you will hear in every native setting, either with or without dancing. Some of it harks back to the ancient slave market, when maidens performed sensuous and provocative dances to the accompaniment of native bands of musicians. It is untamed and raw, but orthodox.<br /><br />In the main, Egyptian music is always dance music. It is usually lively, even though it may be sad in mood. Countless generations, through joy and suffering, have contributed to the musical art of this land. The earthiness of dancing girl and beggar breathe with equal eloquence and power in the music you hear in Port Said, for time has passed without essentially changing these simple hearts who live their lives with dance and song." -- el-bakkar website

title: All the cool kids have done it . . .
author: Richard Joseph
post_content: <span style="font-size:180%;color:#ff6600;"><em><strong>O</strong></em></span>kay, okay. I suppose you’ve all been wondering what exactly happened neigh on four months ago that has kept me from completing a relevant, enjoyable-to-read post of any significant length. I will also suppose that you will not accept some flimsy tale of mild computer problems and laziness. I suppose that you will settle for nothing less than the completely true, white-knuckle action spectacular tale of how I wound up like I am today: computerless, hairless, and aching both physically and emotionally. In that case, listen up, readers, for I will now a tale unfold whose lightest word would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood, make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, thy knotted and combined locks to part, and each particular hair to stand on end, like the quills upon the fretful porpentine, as the poet says.<br /><br />Let’s see . . .. Where to begin . . .. I guess it all started back in the early days of the Thanksgiving vacation. Sam and I were traveling home from the mall after some Christmas shopping. It was about nine o’ clock at night and . . ..<br /><br />The late autumn moon hung low and ominous over the canals of Holyoke as the two Sugrue brothers drove along the back roads of the old factory district. Weak halogen streetlights dimly revealed the crumbling brick facades of some of the city’s oldest buildings. Richard, the elder brother, slowed the maroon Oldsmobile to a sluggish 55 miles per hour.<br />“Sam,” he whispered urgently, “Does anything about that building seem strange to you?” Richard pointed to a particularly large and imposing architectural monstrosity across the canal.<br />“Well, it could be the oddly thriving vines covering the face of the structure, despite the cold. Maybe it’s the new locks on the bridge gate, despite the fact that the building itself looks abandoned. Or it could be the swarms of guards surrounding the perimeter. Lastly, it might just be the giant red and white Umbrella Corporation logo on the gates, the roof, the vehicles, and the guards themselves, you stupid fucking chink.”<br />“Jeezum Crowe! You might be onto something there, amigo.” Richard muttered thoughtfully, bringing the car to a stop 50 feet down the street from the gates. “If that is the Umbrella Corporation, I don’t like them being that close. It spells trouble.”<br />“So you’re stopping across the canal from their stronghold because you’re worried about them being close? Shouldn’t we be getting as far away as possible?”<br />“Listen, monkey fuck,” Richard said vehemently, “these bastards have tried to kill me on no less than three separate occasions. They’ve also tried to kill my friends. Normally that would be enough for me to want revenge, but on top of that they threaten the fabric of global society with their never-ending nonsensical and oft-times flammable machinations. They are constantly attempting to raise the dead, corrupt the youth of the world, and they create monstrous abominations which maim and kill all in their path.”<br />“So?”<br />“Well, granted I admire them for all of those reasons, but keep in mind that they are mostly staffed by pretentious Euro-trash in Armani suits and they test their products on animals.”<br />“Those villains!”<br />“So I figure, if they’re always planning, why not do some eavesdropping and see what they’re up to. That way we’ll be ready the next time they strike. And, as an added incentive we might be able to pull some pre-emptive ass kicking.”<br />“Hmm . . . alright, let’s do it!” Sam assented with gusto.<br />The two boys quietly stepped out of the car and crept quickly over to the towering chain-link fence separating them from the steep drop to the murky canal below. Hiding from the yellowed glow of the streetlights, they moved stealthily down the road until they stood before the imposing wrought-iron gates that closed off the bridge. Rich shuddered. The gates were large and formidable and emanated antiquity. Rusted and covered with thick, clinging ivy, they filled him with a substantial amount of dread.<br />“And how are we supposed to get in, fuck squat?” Sam inquired.<br />Rich soundlessly knelt in front of the locked gates and took a small leather case from his pocket. He slipped out three metal instruments: lock picks.<br />“This’ll just be a second.” Rich said. “Wait. You don’t happen to have a key, do you?”<br />“No.”<br />“Just checking.”<br />Richard expertly manipulated the skinny tools inside the heavy padlock on the gates. After a few minutes of twisting and poking, Rich was reward by a loud click, and the doors swung open a few inches.<br />“Well done,” Sam said. “How’d you learn how to do that?”<br />“I dated a hot cat burglar.”<br />“I think you mean you bought a lock-picking set out of a cheap army surplus catalog and it came with an instructional pamphlet.”<br />“Maybe so . . .. Well, let’s get down to the reconnaissance, amigo. And proceed with caution.”<br />They slipped through the gates and crept through the shadows across the bridge to old factory building, careful to avoid the security staff prowling purposefully about.<br />Richard was surprised to see that the normally flamboyant and exotic Umbrella Corporation was employing human guards. Especially dangerous looking human guards. Moreover, the various workers bustling about the complex seemed uncharacteristically efficient. Something was going on in the Umbrella Corporation. Something big.<br /><br />The factory was much larger than it had appeared from the road. It was part of an expansive complex that contained several adjacent buildings nearly the size of the main structure. The immensity of the operation struck Richard as decidedly sinister. It did not bode well. He decided to tell Sam this, but found that his brother had sneaked off to steal obscure pieces of equipment. Figuring his brother could take care of himself, Richard headed for the main building. He crept around to the side, avoiding the shadow of the formidable front doors. He found an iron ladder attached to the building near the back. Richard climbed four stories to the roof without hesitation, and, using muscles built up from years of roofing, made his way to one of the larger skylights. Wiping some soot and grime from a pane of glass, he peered through at the scene below.<br />He was looking down at a large, darkened room. Taking prominence in the center of the room was a massive black meeting table. There were ten people on each side of it, and one person at each end. The figures along the sides were dressed impeccably in dark suits. Their features were indistinct, their faces shrouded in darkness, but Richard could tell that there was an even distribution of men and women. The ends of the table were slightly illuminated, and he could make out the two figures at each. At one end was a large, solidly built man in a coal black suit. His dark, rugged race was creased in a frown. His dark eyes were peering steadily across the table to the far end. His thick, dark hands lay motionless on the ebony surface in front of him. He was, in short, a dark character. The one part of his person that was not dark was his tie. It was a most remarkable tie, white in the background, with vibrant red and yellow geometric patterns. The remarkable thing was that the shapes were in constant movement, shifting across the fabric in hypnotic swirls. Richard then realized why this dark character was visible when everyone else in the room (save the figure at the other end of the table) was hidden in shadow. The tie gave off its own light. Richard then turned his attention to the figure at the other end of the table and his jaw dropped. Surrounded by a circle of light that shone down from above stood a creature that had haunted his dreams for months. Towering above the two guards on either side of him, his mechanical limbs gleaming in the light, was Captain Adolph Lenin Huzuki-bot 3500.<br /><br />“Holy fuck!”<br />Richard looked up quickly. Sam had returned from his larcenous endeavors and made his way to the roof. He was now looking through the same skylight as his brother.<br />“That’s the Captain, isn’t it, Rich?” asked Sam in numb disbelief.<br />“It is. And that dark character at the other end of the table is Mr. Hazzard, if I’m not mistaken. He was in my Sociology book. He’s a corporate lawyer, employed by the Umbrella Corporation it seems. I wonder what’s going on.”<br />The brothers stopped speaking and turned their attention back to the window the below.<br /><br />“Captain Adolph Lenin Huzuki-bot 3500,” spoke Mr. Hazzard in a rumbling basso which all black people have *cough Underworld cough* “You have been summoned before us, the Umbrella Corporation board of directors, because you have failed to execute your duties on three separate occasions. Your ineffective management skills have cost UC millions and set back our plans for several years. Moreover, you have not made any significant gains through your subsidiary company, Ninja Pirate Incorporated. As that enterprise is owned by the Umbrella Corporation, we expect profits on our investments. You have proven an ineffective leader, a failure, and a financial liability.”<br />“In short, you’ve outlived your usefulness.”<br />These words were not spoken by anyone physically in attendance at the meeting. A mammoth screen behind Hazzard suddenly lit up and a face appeared on it, dominating the entire room. The face was that of a man, Richard could tell that much by the goatee. But its features were fine and effeminate, giving it an androgynous appearance. The man was old, but healthy looking. A pair of pince nez glasses, which were perched upon his aquiline nose, hid his eyes. The lenses of these were an octagonal pattern made up of red and white stained glass triangles. They were the logo of the Umbrella Corporation. He was clad in a blood red suit, with a black shirt and white ascot. His hair was silver and short-cropped. Richard had no idea who he was.<br />“Captain, you cost more than you’re worth.”<br />“Yarr,” interjected the Captain, “Zince ven has the ‘Brella Corperation been about efficiency?”<br />“I’ll admit that the past corporate strategy has been lacking in direction and logic, but for various reasons we have undertaken to establish new policies and become a more effective entity.” He paused here for effect. “Your failure to eliminate the threat posed by those meddlesome students has not impressed me to any extent. I have run out of patience.”<br />“An’ another thing, vy does we have ter keel zose poor students? They were creary fighting in self defense.”<br />“You didn’t seem to mind being appointed this task before.”<br />“I were only forrowing orders.”<br />“Your kindness has no place here. You, Captain, are officially demoted. Henceforth you and your division will be under the supervision of a personally picked high enforcer. Gentlemen,” he said, turning his attention to the council, “allow me to introduce the newest member of the Umbrella Corporation team, vice president Silas Blake.”<br />A pair of automated sliding doors hissed open, filling the darkened hall with white light, and a figure stepped forth. It was a boy of no more than 19, Richard guessed. Of average height and built, he seemed remarkably unassuming. Blake made his way into the room and stood next to the Captain. The doors he entered through slid closed and another beam of light, like that surrounding the Captain, shone down done upon him, so Richard could make him out clearly. He had tussled brown hair and boyish good looks. He peered confidently, a little smugly even, at the assembled council, through mysterious turquoise eyes.<br />“Glad to be here, Doc,” he said as he gave the giant omnipresent head on the screen a jaunty salute.<br /><br />On the roof, Sam laughed. “He’s just a kid!”<br />Richard stared entranced. “He’s gorgeous.”<br />“They think a kid is gonna be better than the Captain- a nine-foot-tall robot pirate Nazi- at killing us?”<br />“I think I’m in love.”<br /><br />Back in the council room, the giant head was speaking.<br />“Silas will be taking over your duties, Captain, beginning with the extermination of those meddlesome kids, including the management of Ninja Pirate Inc, and following into our newest plan, the destruction of the town commons of South Hadley!”<br /><br />On the roof, Sam and Richard stifled screams of abject horror.<br /><br />“The town commons have long been a Mecca for teenagers of the surrounding area. With the restaurants, theatres, and the accursed Thirsty Mind, they have provided sanctuary and place of repose for those otherwise most susceptible to our influence. They must be destroyed. Once they are gone the teenagers of Western Massachusetts will become even more weak-willed and compliant. They will turn to the first helping hand they see. That hand will be ours. We will infect these noxious teenagers with several viruses hidden in our line of junk foods. They will transfer these diseases among themselves and eventually pass them on to their families. Just when the world is on the brink of a worldwide epidemic, a miraculous cure will be developed . . . by none other than the magnanimous Umbrella Corporation. We will become heroes to a panic-stricken world, and we will make obscene amounts of money.” He paused here for emphasis. “But that is not the end of this glorious scheme. The medicine we give out will have powerful addictive properties. Mind-altering properties. People will not be able to live without our specialized drugs. The world will be under our control!”<br />The assembled council dissolved into a chorus of irate objection and confusion.<br />“There’s nothing flammable!”<br />“---no undead!”<br />“Hot ass-kicking babes noticeably absent from---”<br />“---total disregard for company policy---”<br />“This is my will!” the giant head shouted. “This shall be done!”<br />A fearful hush fell over the room.<br />“You all have your orders. Do not fail me.”<br />The screen turned black.<br /><br />On the roof the two brothers looked at each other. No words were said. They knew what they had to do. Silently they made there way back to the car and disappeared into the night.<br /><br /><br />As the Millennium Falcon sped over the bridge toward South Hadley and temporary safety, Richard spoke urgently to Sam.<br />“Sam, this is bad. This is very, very bad.”<br />“What you mean? The Captain is taking orders from a kid and their plot’s more boring than usual. If anything, we’re safer now than ever.”<br />“No. Something isn’t right. Their scheme isn’t the usual wacky and erratic evil plan they’re known for, but it’s also not inherently flawed or flammable. I think it has a chance of succeeding. And Silas strikes me as decidedly dangerous.”<br />“You think he’s hot.”<br />“True, but dangerous as well. We need to call everyone in on this. We need some help.”<br />The car increased in speed toward the center of South Hadley.<br /><br />Back at the old factory, Silas sat in a swivel chair with his designer Italian shoes propped on a desk. In front of him was a massive Umbrella Corporation super computer which was, for the time being, inactive.
