Weary and aching, despite their rapid healing abilities, the combatants nonetheless charged at each other with an ungodly fury. They doggedly traded blows, relentlessly battering each other. Punching and kicking, biting and clawing, they rolled over and over, neither asking for nor giving quarter.<br />Their battle raged across the bridge to the old factory, up and down flights of stairs, around corners, through doorways and back out again.<br />Tony moved almost faster than Richard could follow.<br />Every one of Richard’s punches made Tony feel as though a wrecking ball had hit him.<br />The din of their combat, groans, screams, triumphant yells, grunts of exertion, rose above the creaking of the buildings and the crackling of the fire.<br />Eventually they made their way around the main building and back to the front doors. Tony swung a chop at Richard’s neck, but the beast dodged and sunk his teeth into Tony’s arm. Tony gasped in pain as two-inch-long teeth tore through muscle and ligament. The vampire stopped attacking to cradle his ruined arm as it healed. Richard took advantage of the momentary let up in Tony’s attack. He grabbed Tony’s collar and, bringing him close, head butted the vampire ferociously three times, splitting his lips and breaking his nose.<br />“Who’s the better monster now?” Richard growled.<br />Tony spit out a tooth and managed a fierce, bloody smile.<br />“I’m not through with you yet, shaggy.”<br />Rich’s yellow eyes widened in shock as Tony’s knee connected with his groin. He loosened his grip on the vampire and sank to his knees. Tony slammed a knife into the beast’s neck, stepped back, and with a fiery intensity struck Richard square on the chin with an astounding uppercut, sending him crashing into the front of the building. Richard’s heavy form, coupled with the power of Tony’s hit, cracked the brick façade, and Richard crumpled to the ground.<br />The warriors rested for the second time since their epic battle had begun.<br />Gradually, Richard rose to his hind paws.<br />The opponents locked eyes for what they new would be the last time. It ended here.<br />They had just started their final charge when the old factory behind them finally gave. The whole building exploded outward toward the canal with a tremendous force. Chunks of the front wall flew through the air. Richard and Tony were launched halfway across the bridge, burned and wounded. Flaming bits of the factory hit the oily waters of the canal and ignited them. The water, so contaminated with volatile chemicals, lit the area in a spectacular blaze.<br />Tony and Richard lay unconscious for five minutes, no more than two yards from each other. Eventually they began to move. Gingerly, feebly, they stretched their limbs as their bodies forced shrapnel back out through their skin, healed their burns, and reset broken bones. Though the healing was soon through, the agony was still very much present.<br />Tony stood up.<br />Richard stood up.<br />They could see there was only one way this fight would end. They advanced.<br />“I have to go for a kill,” both thought.<br />Tony drew and eleven-inch knife, bared his glistening white fangs, and hissed.<br />Richard growled, a low, rumbling, dangerous sound, and trudged forward.<br />The werewolf wrapped his claws around the vampire’s throat and head, cutting off the hiss, and began to twist. He was trying to rip his foe’s head off.<br />The vampire’s blade was silver. He rammed it deep into his opponent’s belly. The werewolf’s growl was replaced by the sizzling of flesh: Richard’s allergic reaction to the shining metal. Tony twisted the blade up and around, searching for the heart.<br />Just as the mists of death were clouding over the combatants’ eyes, their lives flashed before them. Improv club, Python skits in front of the school. Celebrity Jeopardy, parties over Tony’s, porno at Richard’s. Countless movies, games, walks, and chats came flooding back to the two friends.<br />Through the haze, Richard saw Tony rambling on in the front seat of Pachuco.<br />“But I digress,” Tony was saying, “I love pop tarts.”<br />Tony could see himself standing next to Richard one fine spring day under the shade of a tree.<br />“Lovely weather,” Tony said.<br />Rich replied, “It’s giving me an erection!”<br />Simultaneously, Richard released Tony and Tony withdrew his dagger. They hugged breathlessly on the rusted bridge over the flaming canal amid the falling snow.<br />“It doesn’t matter who’s better.”<br />“Right, because I think we’ve both proven we’re about equal.”<br />“We coulda learned something from Steve and Amy,” said Tony.<br />Richard looked across the canal to Steve’s van, in which a Goth-chic Amy, clearly embracing her new vampirism, and Steve, halfway between human self and full transformation, were apparently seeing how far they could stick their tongues down each other’s throats.<br />“Oh, okay, said Rich, unraveling and foot of tongue and advancing on Tony.<br />“Take one more step and I’ll stab you in the eye,” said Tony drawing his blade. “I meant we should see past all this nonsense of werewolves and vampires. We’re friends, plain and simple, and always will be.”<br />And with that, the two friends limped slowly across the bridge towards home.<br /><br />As Richard and Tony made their way to their respective rides, a single, unnoticed periscope slid silently beneath the flaming waters of the canal.<br />Below the surface a highly advanced mini-sub hovered, glowing, in the murky depths.<br />Dr. Thaddeus Trans released his finger from the periscope control button and the screen before him went black.<br />He was seated in a large, high-backed, swiveling chair, surrounded by computer consoles which flooded the interior of the submarine with a dull red light. Trans’ effeminate face grew grim in that light.<br />“Very well,” he said angrily. “So those two wish to squander the gifts I have bestowed upon them? They wish to turn their backs on my generous offer? ‘Tis a shame. Their willpower is astounding. They were capable of breaking the influence of my psycho-emotional chemicals. They would have made invaluable generals for my zombie army. Now I suppose I really will have to kill them.<br />“Sung Li, get me Philipe Abattoir on the line,” Trans spoke into an intercom.<br />A flawlessly beautiful Asian face appeared on the monitor in front of him. Her skin was pale and without even the smallest imperfection, like porcelain. Her hair was sleekest ebon, the same color as her seductive almond eyes, and her teasing, pouting lips.<br />Sung Li was Trans’ chief assistant and head interrogator for the Umbrella Corporation. She was an unmatched martial artist and possessed a fantastic scientific mind.<br />“You wish to eliminate those two boys you turned into monsters, Dr.? That’s a shame, they were cute.”<br />“Sadly yes, Sung Li. They declined my offer, what other choice do I have?”<br />“Well, instead of having that leering animal Abattoir kill them, why not have him merely capture them and turn them over to me?”<br />Trans chuckled. “You think you’d be able to convince them to change their minds?”<br />“I am sure of it, Dr. My talents have never failed you before.”<br />The wicked doctor smiled, thinking of Li’s torture methods. “It’s true, Sung Li. You can be very . . . persuasive. Very well, then. Patch me through to Abattoir.”<br />“Yes sir, Dr. Thank you sir.”<br />Sung Li’s face disappeared, to replaced by one not nearly as pleasant.<br />Philipe Abattoir did not work expressly for the Umbrella Corporation. He was a bounty hunter. An ugly term, but it fit Abattoir well. He grinned revoltingly at Trans and spoke to him through a heavy Cajun accent.<br />“Well, well, Doc. How can Ah be of ‘sistahnce today?”<br />“Abattoir, I need you to bring in two bounties. I’m sending the files over to you now.”<br />The Cajun perused the documents.<br />“Mon jou, these lil’ ones be nuthin’ but chillins. I laak hurtin’ chillins.<br />“Be careful, Abattoir, they’re more than they appear.”<br />Abattoir read on.<br />“Ah, you’n raaght about that, Doc. A werewolf anna vampah? Be a good challenge.”<br />“And how goes the search for Silas Blake?”<br />Abattoir frowned. “Well, Ah get him soonah oh latah. He a crafty devil, though. Already killed two ah mah men.”<br />“Make sure you don’t harm any of these bounties too much. I want them brought in alive, no disintegrations.”<br />“As you wish,” said Abattoir, looking disappointed.<br />“Don’t fail me, Abattoir; there’s too much at stake.”<br />“Oh, Ah bring dem in soon, Doc, Ah gah-rahn-tee.”<br />The screen went dark again.<br />Trans leaned back in his chair and mused on the night’s events.<br />“A traitor revealed and two new recruits. That’s worth the loss of one ramshackle headquarters. Meanwhile, our enemies are still unaware of our true plan, which is right now moving ahead of schedule. This is promising to be a banner year for Umbrella.”<br />He chuckled quietly in the dark as his mini-sub sped off into the inky waters of the canal.<br /><br />Richard trudged wearily up to his front door. This had truly been a long day. He called out as he stepped inside his cluttered kitchen and shut the door firmly behind him.<br />“Hey guys, I’m home.”<br />There was no answer.<br />“That’s right,” he said to himself, “Sam is still partying with some friends after tonight’s battle.” His father, he reflected, must have taken the dog and gone to Holyoke to cruise the bars courting some Spanish girls half his age. “I have the house to myself.”<br />“I should probably go online and talk to Tony about the future of Ninja Pirate Inc. And while I’m on I can check out Whippedass.com, my favorite site. Maybe even do a little self-loving . . .” Rich thought grinning.<br />He turned on his computer and while he waited the 10 minutes required for it to boot up, he slipped out of pants, unbuttoned his shirt, and pulled off his socks. He stood before the machine clad only in his boxers.<br />“Maybe I should tend to some of these wounds,” he thought, looking down at the countless cuts, scrapes, burns, and bruises that covered his body, reminders of the night’s battles. There were so many of them, and most of them so grievous, that even with his newly acquired rapid healing it would still take the rest of the night for his body to repair itself. Maybe werewolves heal faster in the heat of battle, with all the endorphins pumping through their systems, he thought. I wonder if Tony feels as bad as I do.<br />He decided upon further contemplation to leave the wounds as they were. I am going to Whippedass.com, he figured. The injuries will make the experience more complete.<br />Richard signed on to AOL and grabbed a handful of tissues. He typed in the address and waited, grinning in anticipation, as the site loaded before him. He had just started to pull down his boxers when the site dissolved and was replaced by the smiling face of the last person he expected to see.<br />“Oh my,” chuckled Silas Blake. “I really didn’t know I did it for you.”<br />Rich scrambled to pull up his underwear, stumbling backward in shock.<br />“You?! How the hell did you . . . ?! What the hell?!<br />“Simple.” Silas explained. “I used cutting-edge bio-electrical technology developed by Umbrella to download a digital version of myself onto a disk. I then sent myself, via AOL, to your computer. Would you believe that the folks at America Online actually helped me to take over your PC? ‘Anything to further screw a customer of ours,’ they said. As we speak I am slowly encrypting all your files, every square millimeter of circuit board, with myself. I am now a part of your computer.”<br />“No!” Richard yelled. “I won’t let you!” He desperately hit control, alt, delete.<br />“I’m afraid that won’t work. You see, for all indents and porpoises, I am your PC.”<br />Richard grabbed a nearby brass pig and cocked his arm back.<br />“We’ll see about that!”<br />He was about to smash the monitor in, wiping the pixilated smirk from Blake’s face when a bolt of electricity shot out of the CD drive and struck Richard in the chest. He violently convulsed and fell to the ground.<br />“Naughty, naughty.” Silas wagged a finger back and forth, his smirk broadening, giving his boyish face a slightly mad look. “No funny stuff or you get another spanking.” He seemed to ponder for a second and then zapped Richard again for emphasis.<br />Richard yelled in pain as the fingers of electricity danced over his body.<br />“You son of a bitch,” he gasped.<br />“Oh you liked it!” Blake taunted.<br />“What do you want?” Richard asked from the floor.<br />“I actually haven’t decided yet. I can’t decide whom to exact my revenge upon first, you and your friends or the Umbrella Corporation. I suppose I’ll stay here, using you and your friends to get at Umbrella, and when that’s finished I’ll kill you one by one.”<br />Richard glared at the screen.<br />“Of course, until then I can always amuse myself by torturing you. For starters, no more online time, meaning your blog is done, as are all IM sessions. I’ll plague you with pop-ups. I’ll break all your burned CD’s. Also, no online time means no more of your favorite pornography sites.”<br />“You monster! Not my blog! I need that. My readers depend on me. If I don’t post not only will they be deprived of my awesomeness, but they’ll think I’m just being lazy.”<br />“Oh I was just getting started. Next I’ll delete all your files. Slowly. For instance, all your blogs, including any in the works.”<br />“No!”<br />“Then, how about some choice music files, like that Brendan Smith original?”<br />“Aaah!”<br />“After those, I’ll delete your pictures, like that sexy one of that girl’s tattoo.”<br />“You leave Sarah out of this!”<br />“Ah ha. Pictures from The Clearing. Those are gone too.”<br />“Enough!”<br />“Easy, Sparky. Another outburst and I’ll paralyze that yapping little dog of yours. All it takes is a few well place jolts to the ------”<br />He never finished. Richard had been pushed beyond the breaking point. He darted forward, faster than Silas could hit, and pulled the computer’s plug out of the wall.<br />Silas faded gradually from the screen.<br />“I’ll be here waiting when you turn me back on . . .”<br />The screen went black.<br />Richard sat on the floor in front of the computer and clutched the brow despairingly.<br />“Well this is an unsettling development,” he muttered shaking his head.<br />He stared sadly at the ominous black screen.<br /><br />He did not wallow in self-pity for long, however. Once he had considered the wild adventures, near misses, and amazing accomplishes of the night, he felt a surge of relief and a glorious sense of accomplishment. Throwing his clothes back on, slipping on his shoes, and grabbing his car keys he was out the door and on his way to Tony’s in moments.<br /><br />Tony’s house was overrun when Richard got there. The lounge and grounds had been inundated with revelers, joyous heroes drunk on victory and cream soda.<br />He found a quiet corner near the pool table and sat watching the merriment with a feeling of profound satisfaction blended with nebulous concerns for the future.<br />Tony came by and sat next him. For a moment, neither said anything, they merely watched.<br />Andrew, Brendan, Marissa, and Meg were playing pool. Sam was running around singing and eating flour. Dave, EJ, and Jake were laughing conspiratorially over the fuse ball table. Caitlin and Amy were having a relaxed conversation over a bowl of chips. Everywhere they looked happiness and contentment abounded.<br />“I think things are going to get better now,” said Tony, still looking at the party.<br />“There’s still a lot to be concerned with. NP Inc, Blake, Trans,” he paused, “us.”<br />Tony turned to look at his comrade in arms.<br />“Look at them. Look at how happy they are. Do you know what their secret is?”<br />Richard shook his head.<br />Tony went on, “It’s not that they are oblivious to the problems facing them, it’s simply that they realize they can face those problems when they come to them.”<br />At this point Sam rolled by on the floor, laughing like a madman and throwing darts at the ceiling.<br />“Even Sam?” Rich asked.<br />“Especially Sam. It’s important release some tension at some point.”<br />Richard was silent for a moment.<br />Then he laughed, slapped Tony on the back, and ran his fingers through his long, curly hair, and got up.<br />“Care for a game of air hockey? And no using vampire speed!”<br />“I could beat you if I were a zombie!”<br />“Care to let some money ride on that?”<br />“You’re on!”<br />The two friends laughed and joined the revelry, temporarily forgetting their troubles and partying long into the night.<br /><br />The next day was Thanksgiving.

title: Jack Acid, Freelance Priest
author: Miracle Jones
post_content: By Miracle Jones<br /><br />The day I met Jack Acid was one of those days when I was sure everybody was secretly working for The Man. Maybe not even secretly. Maybe they were all wearing cinnamon-scented “The Man” Underroos, and I just didn’t get the memo. I was marked, like a terrier’s favorite light-post, and it seemed every bastard I met that day could smell the subterfuge and clueless opposition in my rotten Jockeys.<br /><br />Ultimately, in retrospect, everything turned out for the best. But that day was probably the closest I ever came to taking the NRA up on their standing philosophical proposition and purchasing an automatic weapon. I think I would have tried to rob the police station. “Give me all your justice,” I would have said, “In small, unmarked ballistic packages.” Self-inflicted suicide is so desperate - and I think there must be a certain level of cool in showing up in Heaven riddled with police slugs. Surely “hail of gunfire” deaths get their own wing or something away from the apathetic masses, right next to the “burned up in re-entry” folks.<br /><br />But this story isn’t about my woes, particularly, so let me just give you a quick rundown of where I stood before I get on with the meat and potatoes of this first attempt at chronicling what my life has now become.<br /><br />1) I awaken to the insufferable, psychotic whine of my landlord informing me that I have been evicted for weeks now, and what-the-hell-am-I-still-doing-sleeping-in-His-precious-shithole-of-an-efficiency-apartment. Fair enough. I just can’t quite handle the idea of being homeless yet. It’s like when an amputee’s missing leg begins to itch.<br /><br />2) The library, where I spend most of my days and nights, engaging in what I call “research” and what the rest of the world calls “evading responsibility,” informs me that, due to a new municipal policy and budget restrictions, the library will now only be open every other day and close at 5 PM, placing more of an emphasis on circulation, and no longer stooping to babysit society’s dysfunctional, schizotypal cynics. Fuck.<br /><br />3) For some unaccountable reason or another, somebody has checked out everything P.G. Wodehouse ever wrote. Even the book that I was reading and hid in the toilet paper dispenser in the third floor bathroom. I become convinced a conspiracy against me is brewing. Now it will be months before I figure out whether or not the invincible Jeeves has gotten Bertie Wooster out of another unfortunate marriage proposal. I curse out loud, and William T. Crewcut, jabbering into a cell-phone and wearing an orange t-shirt proclaiming allegiance to some sort of prepositional Christ organization, gives me the eye. I hate that.<br /><br />4) An e-mail from Gourmet Skin magazine announces their insolvency, and offers a sad letter of condolence to all its writers who it now cannot pay due to an increasing proliferation of free internet porn and the effective death of the printed pornographic word. It is possible that I am qualified to do something other than write for the cum-rag press, but then again, it is possible that I am not. Best of luck, say the conveniently bankrupt editors of GS. I consider hiring a lawyer, and then I remember that I already owe Satan a favor or two, myself.<br /><br />5) No more 99 cent value menu at Wendy’s.<br /><br />6) As I am walking down Guadalupe, trying to figure out where I stand karmically, and whether or not faking a British accent will increase my chances of getting a small business loan, an exasperated mother and a goggle-eyed, ice-cream clad toddler (my supernatural stain sense tells me it’s vanilla) come bounding out of one of the numerous, forgettable clothing shops that festoon what used to be The Drag. I give the kid my best smile, and with a prestidigitational flourish, remove my thumb to amuse his no-doubt heavily refined sense of the joyfully grotesque. The kid actually begins to cry. His mother grabs his sticky hand, and yanks him in the opposite direction. Man, I love kids...and damned if they don’t 99.9% of the time love me back. Due to our synchronous maturity level, we usually get along great. Therefore, to ease my ego, and because it has been days since I have bathed, I assume I must smell something awful. Leprous-rainy-day-cottage-cheese-feet awful. Still, this particular cosmic brick-in-the-teeth bums me out maybe more than anything else.<br /><br />So there I was - homeless, jobless, hungry, intellectually unsatisfied, without a friend in the world, and feeling utterly, utterly wretched. And then, to top off my proverbial mug of poison Guinness, as I sat in front of the post office, waiting for the mail and (hopefully) answers to my weekly fiction queries, who should chance to come walking by but Her. And She was with Him. The Two of them Together, only Tongues apart, and glowing like the finest Couple ever to walk the fallen, corruptible world.<br /><br />I would like to say I kept my cool. I would like to say I nodded my head slightly, gave them a cool slit-eyed stare, and went back to chatting up the passers by. I would like to say a lot of noble things about myself, but that day was not to be denied the full run of its wrath, and what actually happened fills me now with irreducible shame. I am only human. And when I get angry, I get creative.<br /><br />Let me just say that it was a private moment of ignominy, there was much unpleasantness, and all of us - myself, Her, Him, Johnny Law, that sweet old lady collecting for charity, the United States Postal Service, the Texas State School for the Deaf, and many of the finest words in the Webster’s dictionary - are past that particular point in our lives. I forgive myself, but it was not pretty. After collecting my pants and proving to the beat cop that I was not in fact on PCP, I was sent on my way with a warning, having not technically done anything illegal. Not technically, not in Austin. The cop took pity on me, I now realize. She, however, never looked back.<br /><br />And that was when Fate would decide that I had suffered enough. That was when a dark wind would blow the weathervane-thin indicator of my attention in an entirely new direction. That was when I saw the flyer that would lead me to Jack Acid.<br /><br />It caught my eye out of nowhere, pasted sideways across one of those public forum posts between a band poster (“Bloody Stool” opening for “Abraded Elbow Lesion”) and an open proclamation to the world that Socialism is the answer to all manifest problems. The flyer must have been a month old. I couldn’t read the bottom half, as it was obscured by a pathetic looking picture of a lost dachshund, but the top half was enough to hijack my self-pity and get me curious. I looked to see if anyone else was watching, and then snapped it off with a quick flick of my wrist to get a better look. It was pretty grimy. In faded gold-leaf lettering on a baby-blue background were the words: ROOMMATE NEEDED. FREE RENT. NO CATCH. NO SHIT. I AM LOOKING FOR ONE IN A MILLION - I AM LOOKING FOR A MIRACLE.<br /><br />There were slots for toothy little tags on which one would ordinarily find a phone number, but no tags left.<br /><br />“Too bad,” I said to myself, looking for a trash can to toss it into. “This almost looks legit.” It couldn’t have been advertising. There was no hook.<br /><br />I began to get the unmistakable prickly feeling of being watched. I spun around in the air, expecting a pickpocket. I was wrong. Standing there, staring at me, and then laughing at me, was a sight for the sorest eyes this side of an Antarctic snow storm.<br /><br />“Zeke!”<br /><br />“Mr. Jones, I presume.”<br /><br />A seven-foot tall, bespectacled man wearing a T-shirt that says “God used to be my co-pilot, but then we crashed in the mountains of Nepal and I was forced to eat him” can’t help but make you smile. Plus, Ezekiel Sandoz and I grew up together. We met in fifth grade when I kicked the everloving crap out of Elliot Michaels one day in computer lab for making fun of him past all reason. He just wouldn’t shut up about Zeke being a character on the Oregon Trail – “You got snakebit, Zeke” “Zeke, you died of a broken leg” - and it had really started to annoy me. It eventually came to a head, I had to fight him, and even though I got my nose broken and lost the respect of almost every girl in the neighborhood who thought I was a sweet elementary school innocent, I won a friend for life.<br /><br />We got along great back then, and we still do. Zeke has an incredibly religious, slightly insane family and I don’t have one to speak of at all, so we compromised. I occasionally got a Christmas, and he occasionally got drugs and laid. Eventually, Zeke hit a late puberty, where he rocketed up from the ground like some sort of experimental genetically-modified oak, and I still reap the benefits of intimidating protection from time to time. Inside both of our minds, though, he is still shorter than I am.<br /><br />The last time I had seen him was at his graduation. He was now working on his PhD in Philosophy, and didn’t have as much time for kicks and hijinks.<br /><br />“Homeless again, Jones?” said Zeke.<br /><br />“You know it. Hey, you remember that time we went around and tried to painstakingly turn every speed-limit sign in Austin that had a 3 on it into an 8? I was just thinking about that the other day. We got greedy. We should have just made 2s into 3s. Nobody would even have noticed.”<br /><br />“Yeah, but where would be the radically empty symbolic gesture there?” said Zeke, grinning.<br /><br />“It’s a fine line, to be sure,” I said.<br /><br />Zeke picked me up in a bone crushing bear-hug, and then set me back down, where I could recuperate and pop back together my telescoped joints. Sucker-punch style, he snatched the flier out of my hand as I stretched, examined it like it was a rat turd in a jar of peanut butter, and then began to fumble around in his disproportionately tiny wallet with his huge, rough hands. He looked like the most gigantic little old lady ever. I think I even heard him cluck his tongue.<br /><br />“Hmmm...yes...I know it’s in here somewhere. I have a present for you, you runty little white man. As I approached, I saw you staring at that roommate-wanted sign there like it was a 6-month Papal indulgence, and it occurred to me that I have the missing piece of your puzzle. I found it glommed onto the bottom of my shoe the other day, and I kept it because it seemed so odd. I thought it might come in handy. This is what you might call an outstanding, improbable coincidence.”<br /><br />“You know me, Zeke. ‘Improbable Coincidence’ is stenciled on the underside of each of my eyelids.”<br /><br />He grunted in satisfaction and amazingly pulled out one of the flier’s mislaid tag incisors. It was the same unusual shade of blue, and had the same gold-leaf writing. I tried to match it up with the tear-marks, and found that it had come from the very last slot on the left. Bafflingly, it read: YOUR PHONE NUMBER IS 555 - 0121. GET READY TO BE SHOCKED.<br /><br />“It’s certainly not my phone number,” said Zeke. “I thought it was just a reject from the shittiest fortune cookie company ever.”<br /><br />The payphone behind us began to ring. Zeke and I looked at each other. A ringing unattended payphone is spy movie fodder. My brain began to tingle. I leaned over to check, and sure enough, the payphone’s number was 555 - 0121. Perhaps things were looking up.<br /><br />“Better answer it,” said Zeke. “I’m late for class, and if I remember correctly, the last time I got involved in one of your irresponsible forays into the outer darkness, we both got arrested. I think I still have community service hours to do. Let me know how it all works out.”<br /><br />He took off, leaving me to my enlightenment. I watched him leave - slightly frustrated. I kind of wanted him to buy me lunch. But he knew my weakness.<br /><br />I picked up the handset.<br /><br />“Hello? If this is James Bond, let me just say I think you are a lackluster authoritarian toad.”<br /><br />“You must be my miracle,” said the voice at the other end. It was smooth, and sedate. Clipped, yet almost catatonically calm. I started to respond, but I was cut off. “In polite society, my name is Jonathan Acid. But my friends call me Jack. As in Kennedy, or Ing Off. Since we are now formally introduced, I need you to first do a favor for me, and then we will discuss my needs and how we are going to decorate.”<br /><br />“Hold on,” I said, “Just to get things straight. This is about the free room, right? What’s with the elaborately cryptic escapade here? Am I bugged?”<br /><br />“Don’t bother thinking about how this is all happening right now. I’ll explain later, when time is not so pressing a concern. What I need you to do presently, is to go as fast as you can to the corner of 29th and Guadalupe, behind the vendors and fronts. There you will find a gigantic, peach-colored dumpster, locked and latched. You will also find a bolt cutter underneath a big bag of Crunchee-Tatums Ketchup Flavored Potato Crisps. Cut those locks, pocket them, and get inside the dumpster. Sit quietly, stay attentive, and I will be along shortly to fill you in further. I know this is odd, but if you can’t handle it, let me know now. It’s a good sign that you haven’t hung up so far, but most people can’t stomach this much of a deviation from consensus, normative situations. You will be breaking the law, and I need to know the level of complicity with which you are comfortable. You picked a good day, my friend...this may be our last chance.”<br /><br />What did I have to lose? I started to say something witty, like “Buddy, I think you may just be the answer to every one of my fictional prayers,” or “I was born illegitimate, and I’ve been trying to top it ever since,” but instead I just said, “I’m on my way,” and hung up. This was cool as a porno popsicle, and I could play all day.<br /><br />I turned up my collar and sleazed my way to the given location as fast as I could. I got a lot of blank stares. Sometimes I like to pretend I am in a zombie movie and people are very slowly trying to eat my brains. Based on the way I feel every morning when the sun hits my eyeballs, I think they may just get a chunk or two while I am asleep. Today, however, I moved through the streets like a svelte, high-octane, feline slinking machine, and I was even fairly certain I wasn’t being followed.<br /><br />The dumpster was right where Jack had said it would be. This was, I must say, a classy dumpster. It was more like a trash utility shed. It had four walls, was big enough to fit a van inside, and even seemed to be insulated. I could understand why it had locks on it - any self-respecting member of the vagrant persuasion would be more than happy to hole up here and perform their various drug related rituals free from the inclement elements and the prying eyes of justice.<br /><br />I looked for the bag of ketchup chips, found it, removed the bolt cutters, and pocketed them. I circled the shed to make sure there was no one hiding behind it, or that none of the employees of the surrounding shops and restaurants were taking advantage of its concealing size to cadge a quick smoke or a grope. Satisfied, I whipped out the cutters, and snipped off the locks. I picked them up from where they fell clanking to the concrete and stowed them in my jeans.<br /><br />The dumpster was almost empty. There was a single Hefty sack in one of the corners, and a soggy pile of old newspapers. I thought it would be dark and I would have insects and rats to contend with, but instead light poured through a huge hole in the ceiling, a result of what looked to be some sort of chemical corrosion. The edges of the hole were sharp and irregular, and looked chewed.<br /><br />I sat down on the stack of newspapers and began once more to examine the mystery flier and its corresponding tag.<br /><br />In the direct sunlight, I noticed something strange. Attached to the top of the flier by a piece of clear tape was an almost invisible, razor-thin strand of anomalous fiber. When I had grabbed the flier so hastily, I must have snapped it off of whatever it was attached to, because I could tell by the ragged end that it had led somewhere. Curiouser and curiouser.<br /><br />A knock at the door interrupted my inspections and cogitations. I wasn’t sure whether to answer it or not. Before I could make up my mind, my problem was solved for me. In walked the man who could only be Jack Acid. Only this person could match the name and that laconic, hypnotic, narcotic of a voice.<br /><br />“Hello, hello,” said Jack. He was roughly my age and height, and we shared the same build, but the similarities stopped there. He was dressed in a bright pink, almost fluorescent, three-piece suit. In lieu of a necktie, he wore a slender piece of mirror around his neck that gave the appearance of a tie quite convincingly until you looked at it twice and saw yourself looking back. His features were fine and thin, childlike without being pretty or dainty. His hair was shoulder length - dyed blue - and he looked as if he hadn’t shaved in a week or so. He took lanky to a new extreme, but the way he moved, it was as if he was poured like olive oil into the space he would occupy in each subsequent passing moment. The closest analogue I can come up with is that he moved the way professionals - real professionals - have sex. He had grace. I liked him.<br /><br />I offered my hand to shake. He put a sandwich into it.<br /><br />“I got you some calories. Eat, and I’ll explain. We don’t have much time, but there is a minimum amount of information that must be conveyed to you to keep your head above water.”<br /><br />He shut the door behind him. I began to eat. Can you blame me? I suppose it could have been poisoned, but as I said, I liked the guy.<br /><br />“Alright...I’ll keep it simple, citizen,” said Jack. “This is our new digs. Not this particular dumpster precisely, but at least the same model. We are going to get a new one, untainted by the soiled remains of civilized waste. Brass tacks: we are about to engage in a felony of epic ...well semi-epic, anyway... proportions. Criminal Mischief 6703: Theft of a Municipal Trash Receptacle. But don’t feel too bad about it. As you can see...” He pointed with his pinky to the hole in the ceiling. “This particular trash receptacle is no longer functional, and is therefore slated for removal, post-haste. Do you know what they do with dumpsters when they no longer work, my friend?”<br /><br />“No. What?”<br /><br />“They throw them away. And we are merely going to benefit, parasitically, from their absurd insistence on cosmetic virtue.”<br /><br />“How convenient.”<br /><br />“Not really...the hole was my doing. Easy as squirtable cheese. Now, pay attention! In approximately...” he pulled back his sleeve and revealed a Felix-the-Cat wristwatch. The eyes even moved. I suppressed a giggle. “...seven minutes, the two gentlemen charged with removing and replacing this particular trash receptacle will be arriving. Follow my lead. I don’t have much of a plan, because I like to stay open to the flexibility of improvisation, but the ultimate goal is to catch them by surprise, render them insensible, and abscond with their delivery. These two fellows are not the brightest neon in the beer sign, but they do have size on us, so it may be tricky. Especially since, due to certain moral decalogues to which I must adhere, I will not be able to do anything violent.”<br /><br />“Why not?” I asked.<br /><br />“Just pretend I’m your grandmother,” he said.<br /><br />“They say my Nana was a teamster.”<br /><br />“Yeah, well. I just can’t. There’s no time to get into it.”<br /><br />“Fair enough. The name’s Jones, by the way.”<br /><br />“First or last?”<br /><br />I shrugged.<br /><br />“Boring. I shall, of course, call you Miracle. It’s only natural. That is what I requested, and that is what you have become. So what do you do Miracle?”<br /><br />“I write. Oh yeah, and sometimes I agitate for social justice. Hey, listen won’t they come looking for our stolen little hideaway when they realize it’s been snatched?”<br /><br />“Certainly not. They will be much too embarrassed. They’ll simply bring another one. The city has a trash budget that could take care of the homeless problem tomorrow. We will park our new home somewhere out of the loop, and defend it with wits and class.”<br /><br />I finished my sandwich, impressed. Something was still bothering me, though.<br /><br />“So how’d you know you’d find somebody to help you today? Seems a bit reckless. And what makes you think I would be into living in a dumpster with you, buddy?”<br /><br />“Who wouldn’t be? And it wasn’t really that reckless, actually. I’ve been changing the locks on this dumpster every day for weeks now. When that doesn’t work, I slash tires...falsify documents...make prank phone calls. Anything to stall until I found the right muscle. Being a monkeywrench to the bureaucracy machine is like being a window washer at NORAD. Easy. If you truly hate the system as much as I do, you’re in luck, because it’s just so mindless to manipulate. They keep showing up and going back to the station, and they get paid either way. And to answer your second question further, you are the only one who has responded with anything like enthusiasm to my little interview. The flier you took was connected to a small radio transmitter hidden inside the hollow poster pylon that alerted me whenever the flier was jostled by the violence of someone, say, pulling off one of the tags. You evidently pulled off the whole damn flier. Look, when I said I needed a roommate, I was holding back a bit. What I really need is actually something much more difficult to find. And I always trust in coincidence and synchronicity to do my dirty work. What I really need is...”<br /><br />Without warning, the door opened up, catching us off guard. The garbagemen were early. While talking, we hadn’t heard them creep up on us. Two bowlegged men in matching brown jumpsuits stood there with wide ovals of shock on their pusses, staring at me and my sandwich, and Jack and his suit. However, when they regained their composure, they were majorly...nay, royally...pissed off. I got the impression they had been waiting to find out who had been messing with their schedule for weeks now, and were very excited about turning that person into something prone and twitching. However, it had been a world-record bad day for me, and they had interrupted my new friend in the middle of what could potentially be some sort of startling revelation. Did I mention I’m just a bit psychotic? With a right cross, and then a follow-up blow to the stomach to get him low enough for an uppercut (which I delivered with utter grace), I felled the first one, and then used his body to knock the other one down. I gave the second guy a pulled kick to the head, and he joined his chum in the magic land of dreams and swirls. No big thing. Zeke would have scoffed: they were certainly no Elliot Michaels.<br /><br />Immediately, Jack bent down and checked their pulses.<br /><br />“Excellent. Good discipline. Their injuries will be minor.” After inspecting them, Jack looked a little green.<br /><br />I grabbed their truck keys. “Alright, Mr. Jack Acid. I’ll help you steal this dumpster. But as far as being your new roommate, we’ll have to see. I, too, like to stay open to the flexibility of improvisation.”<br /><br />Jack smiled for the first time. “We won’t be stealing their truck for good,” said Jack, “And we don’t want to get the police involved, so we must bring it right back here as soon as we take this dumpster to where we need it. I have the perfect place in mind. Let’s really hurry, though, before they awaken.”<br /><br />I put my foot on the truck’s sideboard, ready to climb up. Jack had stopped, and was looking at me with new eyes. I noticed for the first time that he had my copy of Wodehouse’s Right Ho, Jeeves tucked under his arm. I was not surprised.<br /><br />“Miracle, I was going to say, what I really need is a partner.”

title: Thoughts on the World
author: Guido
post_content: I suppose I should make some sort of update!<br /><br />Life was a bit overwhelming for the last month of 2008...  final exams, final papers, working... it just all seemed to come together in a mass... and then it was over!<br /><br />I passed everything, with fairly decent marks and I'm pleased with the results.<br /><br />Between the finish of exams and Christmas, I worked full-time at my job, which helped to refill the coffers a bit, and it definitely kept me active for the time before Christmas.<br /><br />On Christmas Eve, I made the journey home to my family's home (and Vanessa).  We had a great Christmas gathering with all the usual suspects in attendance.  Two days later, Vanessa's family gathered at V's parents' and we had <span style="font-weight: bold;">Christmas Dinner part II (The Revenge of the Cranberries)</span>. It was a nice get-together, and I really do think that I'm going to fit into the family quite comfortably.<br /><br />Oh yeah, I'm getting married in four months.  Less than.  May 2.  I guess we'd better get that guest list finalised.  I'm constantly torn with who I can invite because, unfortunately, the hall where we're having the reception (my church) isn't overly large, and we're limited to 180 or so people... which really isn't very many when you take into account the large size of both our families, and our copious amount of friends.  Do any etiquette experts have any thoughts on how to gracefully approach this? perhaps posting this thought on my blog is a bad / good idea...?  I'm in a bind, either way... the church where we're having the wedding would probably hold everyone we'd like to invite, but the reception hall is just too small.  Blah.  And no, changing the reception hall location is not an option...<br /><br />Today on my way home from school i was considering the irony of having ads for car dealerships on the side of public transit buses...  advertising on the competition.  Genius.<br /><br />I was thinking about the railway today as well.  In Canada there's a strong affection for the railway because it was this "iron ribbon" that brought Canada together in Confederation... it's what made it possible.  When someone rides VIA Rail these days the trains are (not irregularly) delayed by freight trains passing especially if the passenger train was behind schedule.  Apparently passenger trains are a second priority on the rails.  So anyways, this thought ran through my mind and suddenly it clicked that the rail line that is so revered in Canadian history wasn't built to move people across the continent as I'd often assumed... it was built to move goods. Trees.  Ores.  Coal. How disillusioning to think that this symbol of Canadiana is simply a tool for business...  maybe I'm just naive, but that realisation disappoints me greatly.<br /><br />Sorry for the randomness... just had to get those thoughts out!

She had been playing with her red ball and it had fallen in a hole in the street and she fell in while trying to get it out. I ran over and before anybody could stop I jumped into the hole. It reminded me of a worker's hole. It had platforms and wires and stuff hanging everywhere and I could smell gas. I looked up and saw my sister leaning over the hole looking down at me. She was yelling for Em and me. I said I was alright and then I heard a muffled cry. I looked over and I could see Em sitting on one of the platforms. She was crying and holding her red ball. I said"Come here, Em. Come to Aunt Jessie." and she crawled over to me. I wrapped her in my arms and climbed as far up to my sister as I could and then lifted her up. My sister grabbed her and pulled her to safety just as the hole I was in exploded.......Yea, I woke up then. I was sweating and I felt like I couldn't breathe. I remember thinking that Em was very pretty. She had blonde hair instead of red like Levi's. But she was pretty nonetheless.<br /><br />Anyway, the next night I had a dream that I was pregnant, and the father was either Robby or Drew. They are brothers with whom I work with. It was really weird because they kept asking which was the father and I had no idea. I didn't remember being with either or them. It was really weird.<br /><br />Then the night after that one I had a dream where I was at Wal-Mart and for some reason there was a pile of snakes in the floor. Anyway, I was crying like crazy b/c I didn't want to be near them. I was really scared. They made me grab a bag that had a snake in it and it kept poking its head above the bag and trying to strike me hands that were holding the handles. Anyway, I kept saying I don't want to. but they said they would fire me and I was like idc, fire me but I'm not messing with the snakes. I was crying the entire time. I was crying really hard and I felt like<em> </em>I couldn't breathe b/c I was so scared of the snakes. Anyway, I woke myself up crying. I cry for a few more minutes after I woke up.<br /><br />Well, those are my dreams for the past few days. I don't know if I am really stressed or depressed or something, but don't really know it so it comes out in my dreams. I don't know, but they were all weird.<br /><br />I guess I am going to go now. I have letter to write...:: grins::<br /><br />Later.<br /><br />P.S. You can write me, too. It doesn't have to go in order. I write. You write. I write. You write. Break the mold.</span></strong>

title: Just a Quickie...
author: Jon
post_content: The end of another week in Audley. Various schools clubs & Assemblies and now, finally, half term. It only seems like a few weeks since Christmas, and I guess, really, it is. But I have a week to get on with admin and prep for the new youth service "Express".<br /><br />It's all very exciting. I just organised for a member of the church to head up the all important "Cake Ministry Team" and everything else is going just fine. Also this week should give me a chance to finish off the all new church website, and finally do the chimney breast in our lounge, but who knows? Watch this space.<br /><br />Lent is such a wierd time. You give up stuff for God, but only if it's really bad for you anyway. I thought the idea of lent was to give up stuff that actually did you no harm, so that it was purely about putting God first. Maybe I have a warped view on this issue. Let me know your views.<br /><br />Saying that... I actually didn't give up anything for lent. My contribution is a set of 40 scripture verse "flash cards" on my study desk. One for each day (suprisingly) but even they are still set to day number one. Never mind. I just have some catching up to do.<br /><br />I'm actually really frustrated tonight.<br /><br />Ross & I decided that after me beating him several times at FIFA on the PS2 that we should be completely daft and get a cheap trophy to swap bewteen houses depending on who is reigning FIFA champ. (sounds sad eh?) and tonight, for the first time so far, Ross won and took the trophy home. My heart was broken (well, not maybe that severe). I MUST regain the title, for my own sanity's sake.<br /><br />I really don't know if anyone reads this blog ever. But at least it gives me a chance to vent my frustrations and get things of my chest.<br /><br />And finally...<br /><br />Believe it or not, yesterday Lara & I went to starbucks, but that's not the amazing bit. On the way there. Lara starts singing this song and then says, "It's really wierd, I can't think where I've heard that song, but I can't get it out of my head." Sounds like a fairly normal thing to say huh? Well, it would be, but it was a song that (wait for it)... I WROTE!! nearly 2 years ago and haven't ever really sung it since. I Cannot believe that Lara had no idea she was singing one of my songs. How odd. It's also inspired me to finally write the second verse that I never got round to.<br /><br />Right, That's it. So long, and thanks for all the fish!

title: Letter from Mart to Aaron
author: Rhubarbee Mommee
post_content: <DIV><FONT face=Arial size=2> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">Read: Ezekiel  2:1-3:4</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">Blessed are the undefiled  in the way, who walk in the law of the Lord!&nbsp; --Psalm 119:1</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">Honey ants survive in  difficult times by depending on certain members of their group known as "honey  pots." They take in so much nectar that they swell up until they resemble little  round berries, hardly able to move. When food and water become scarce, these  ants act as "social stomachs" and sustain the entire colony by dispensing what  they have stored in their own bodies.</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">Similarly, the messenger  of God must fill his heart and mind with the truths of Scripture. Only as he is  faithful in applying the Word of God to his own life can he honestly give its  nourishing encouragement and exhortation to others.</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">The Lord told the prophet  Ezekiel to eat a scroll that contained a message full of "lamentations and  mourning and woe" (Ezekiel 2:10). Because he was submissive to the Lord and  applied the lesson to his own heart first, he could boldly present the  life-giving message to all who would listen.</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">As believers, we too must  develop a "social stomach" by digesting the truths of the Bible and allowing the  Spirit of God to make them a part of our lives. Then, filled with God's Word, we  can speak effectively to others who are in need of spiritual food.&nbsp; --Mart  De Haan</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">As we read Your Word, O  Lord,<BR>Our spirit will be fed;<BR>We then can share with others<BR>That  precious living bread.&nbsp; --D. De Haan</FONT></P> <P><FONT face="Georgia, Times New Roman, Times, Serif">Jesus said, "I am the  bread of life."&nbsp; --John 6:35</FONT></P></FONT></DIV>
